results.title: [Orwell Michaelis Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This collection of home movies, originally filmed on 8mm and 16mm film, was taken between 1938 and 1956 by Orwell Michaelis. The collection was donated to ACMI by Michaelis’s daughter, Sally Cohen, and her husband Sheldon Cohen. The films show life in Melbourne including the 1956 Olympic Games, a fishing trip to Bermagui in NSW, and holidays in Indonesia.

This is a home movie from the Michaelis family of early Melbourne. ‘Australian Scenes’ is the title on screen and starts with a lovely view from the Yarra looking back to the city skyline. The river bank is packed as an exciting rowing regatta takes place. A great shot facing south from the top of Swanston Street and then the Shrine of Remembrance. We see a passing parade of Australian Army personnel in their slouch hats. A crowd on the steps of the Old Treasury Building. ‘Flemington, Cup Day, 1940’ is next with crowds of men in hats and wide shots of the running of the race and winners circle. A tennis match is played in front of a sold-out crowd in the ‘1946 Davis Cup Challenge’ at Kooyong’s tennis courts. A very scenic ‘Picnic at Warrandyte’ reflects a relaxing day out with the family in the country. There is footage of Australian native animals at what is possibly Healesville Sanctuary. ‘Bayside Scenes’ shows families enjoying the cooling waters of Port Phillip Bay. ‘Autumn at Macedon’ is a brief scene of trees in autumn colours. We then see the 1956 Olympic Games opening in Melbourne and the parade of athletes, releasing doves and the lighting of the flame. The film shows some events shot from the stands.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:35:00:00 rowing regatta on the Yarra
00:52:00:00 Melbourne street scene with vintage cars and tram #64. Facing south from the top end of Swanston Street.
00:59:00:00 St Kilda Road with Shrine of Remembrance in the distance; tram tracks and vintage cars
00:01:15:00 Shrine of Remembrance with people assembled on stairs
00:01:23:00 Melbourne Street scene, pedestrians and cars
00:01:28:00 possibly an Anzac Day march led by an army band and followed by soldiers
00:01:54:00 spectators crowd on the steps on the Old Treasury Building
00:02:06:00 Melbourne Cup Day, Flemington 1940. Punters crowd around the bookmakers – one being M. Labb
00:02:19:00 race horses being led around the mounting yard
00:02:47:00 footage of race (possibly the Melbourne Cup) shot from the grand stand
00:03:00:00 officials and jockey Andy Knox assemble for the cup presentation
00:03:07:00 1946 Davis Cup Challenge footage of Kooyong Centre Court and crowds in the grandstand
00:03:41:00 men’s singles match footage
00:03:51:00 men’s doubles match footage
00:04:29:00 close-up of the Davis Cup trophy with onlookers inspecting it
00:04:43:00 river in Warrandyte with swimmers on the bank
00:05:06:00 an old-style fireplace bush BBQ with chops and a billy boiling on the grill
00:05:10:00 close-up of a delicious looking BBQ’d lamb chop
00:05:13:00 family bush picnic in bucolic surrounds, eating picnic fare and sitting on blankets
00:05:23:00 rural scene with lake or dam and cabins with smoking chimneys and vintage cars parked around the cabins
00:08:46:00 Melbourne Olympic Games 1956 Opening Ceremony booklet or program
00:08:51:00 exterior of Melbourne Olympic stadium
00:09:09:00 interior of the Olympic stadium
00:09:40:00 atheletes enter the main stadium for the opening march and parade around the track
00:10:41:00 doves are released in to the stadium
00:10:48:00 Ron Clarke enters the stadium carrying the Olympic torch
00:10:58:00 shot of the Olympic cauldron alight with country flags in the background
00:11:26:00 track and field winners on podium

results.title: Neon
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Alex Proyas and Salik Silverstein
results.brief_description: A single-frame time-lapse journey through Sydney, the surrealistic city. Figures dart in and out of the shadows of the night. A kaleidoscope of imagery flies by - incorporates people in subways, cars on freeways, city streets and buildings. The music (by Fad Gadget) drives the images to a tumultuous climax.

results.title: The Repco-Brabham story
results.creator_credit: Cine Service Production and Geoffrey Thompson
results.brief_description: Briefly shows manufacture and testing of racing cars by the Brabham Racing Organisation in England, followed by views of the 1965 Tasman Series motor races in Australia and New Zealand, Jack Brabham and others competing in Brabham cars. Finally, manufacture of a new Repco engine in Australia is shown.

results.title: Touch wood: five Tasmanian woodworkers
results.brief_description: About five men who live in Tasmania and earn their living by working with wood. David Ralph makes small souvenir animals and furniture from horizontal wood; Kevin Perkins makes furniture which allows the natural shape of the wood to be shown; Merv Gray and Peter Mevre make bowls and spheres, and Peter Taylor sculptural pieces.

results.title: Nippers, chompers, grinders
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Judy Nelson
results.brief_description: A film on dental hygiene for children ages 5-8. Janis, who refuses to brush her teeth, disappears down the plughole in order to escape that boring task. She meets three monsters, Nippers, Chompers and Grinders, each with specific tooth ailments and helps them overcome their disabilities. Voices: Valma Bolton, Colin Van Cao, Evelyn Krape, Stephen Radic, Claire Dobbin.

results.title: Zvenigora (Musical Soundtrack)
results.brief_description:
Dovzhenko’s most audacious film combines ancient folklore with modern events in ranging over many centuries of Ukrainian history with a political aim of obliquely linking modern revolutionary Ukraine with its distant past. For Dovzhenko the fresco-like narrative was what he described as ‘a catalogue of my creative possibilities’. The four part structure with a strange quest for treasure at its centre, incorporates a series of bracketing devices to enclose such eccentric episodes as those involving a vampire-like monk, midsummer rituals on the river and a toytown battle. Also available on 16mm.

Credits: Director, Alexander Dovzhenko ; writer, Mikhail Johansen, Yuri Yurtik ; photography, Boris Zavelev.
Cast: Mikola Nademsky, Semyon Svashenko, Alexander Podorozhny.

holdings.name: 35mm film; Limited Access Print (Section 2)

results.title: Zvenigora
results.brief_description: Zvenigora is a complex yet compelling fantasy, presenting the story of a group of Russian peasants and their strong ties with the earth through a series of simple yet strikingly beautiful images. Spanning a period of a thousand years, the film relates the eternal struggle between needing to nurture the land and wanting to strip it of its treasures. A wealth of magical images fill and frame the landscape, from the wizard monk whose death-like countenance terrorises the invaders to the man who advertises his own suicide as theatrical entertainment then absconds with the box office takings. This film is as much a parable about human nature as it is a representation of the struggles of the Russian peasantry, using technical experiments similar to those of Georges Melies to embellish the transcendental nature of the subject. Zvenigora is the fourth film by Russian film master Alexander Dovzhenko, who began his career in film in 1926 after working as both a cartoonist and painter. Despite negative critical reaction to Zvenigora, it was the forerunner of his more celebrated films Arsenal (1929), Zemlya (1930), and Ivan (1932), which perpetuated his interest in honouring the lives and struggles of peasants, and served as a tribute to his heritage as a man of the Ukraine.
